title: TV Producer’s North Tribeca Townhouse to List for $14.995 Million
text:
“I used to have an office just down the street from this house,” said Michael Davies, president of Sony Pictures entity Embassy Row. “I would walk past the house, through north Tribeca, day after day, and it was empty [...] imagining myself in it.”



The light flooding the Collister Street townhouse in north Tribeca is what ultimately convinced Mr. Davies, 53, to buy it, he said, in 2005 for $8.32 million with his partner, Claude, according to property records.



The Tribeca townhouse will list Tuesday for $14.995 million for the first time, as Mr. Davies bought it new off-market, according to Tamer Howard, the listing agent from Douglas Elliman. Ms. Howard, Raphael De Niro, Matt DeGroot and Maggie Leigh Marshall of Douglas Elliman, in association with Billy Rose and Natasha Barrett of The Agency, have the listing.



The building, Hubert Condominiums, owns the air rights above the one-story building directly behind it, so the townhouse gets direct sunlight through its 20-foot-tall floor-to-ceiling windows.

More: Historic Manhattan Townhouse Hitting Market for $12.5M

Kenneth Chen for Evan Joseph Studios

The townhouse comprises five bedrooms and six bathrooms as well as an “epic man cave,” Mr. Davies said, adding that he coined the term in his ESPN soccer column, which ran from 2002 until it was turned into the ESPN soccer podcast “Men in Blazers” in 2011.



Mr. Davies is also known for his work as a television producer on “Watch What Happens Live with Andy Cohen,” “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee,” ESPN's “2 Minute Drill,” and the U.S. version of “Who Wants to be a Millionaire.”



The 6,500-square-foot home also features a one-car attached garage, a private roof terrace back garden, a library/screening room and elevator access. The expansive master bedroom includes a walk-in closet and en-suite marbled bathroom. One of the things that makes it particularly unique, Mr. Davies said, is that it is a townhouse serviced by a 24-hour doorman and porters.

More: Four-Bedroom Brooklyn Penthouse to List for $7.5 Million

Mr. Davies moved into the house in 2008, according to Ms. Howard, and has made updates and renovations over the years, including repolishing the floors, repainting the walls, and updating the appliances within the last year, Mr. Davies said.



“The thing I will never forget is bringing back my daughter, Ingrid,” who was 18 months old at the time, Mr. Davies said. “That was one of my first ever memories in that house.”



Mr. Davies said that the townhouse has been a family home for him, helping raise three children: a 14- and 15-year-old girl and an 8-year-old boy. “But there have been some great parties there as well,” he added.



From Penta: Porsche Unveils its First All-Electric Car

Mr. Davies said his family is grown up and his career has brought him more to the West Coast, where he recently purchased a home in West Hollywood right behind Chateau Marmont that he has been eyeing for some time.

He also owns a home in Bridgehampton, New York, and there is no reason to own three large properties, he added.



Although Mr. Davies said he is sad to say goodbye to Tribeca, an area well-known for its art, food and colorful culture, as well as its charming cobblestone streets and architecture, there is one gripe: “The models and photographers taking photographs in the perfect light on Collister Street,” he said. “But it’s a nuisance I’ll take.”
